headings.title: What makes an album the greatest of all time?
headings.sub: Examining 30 years of Rolling Stone’s “Greatest Albums of All Time” Rankings
headings.byline: by Chris Dalla Riva and Matthew Daniels

introfirst.value: In 2003, Rolling Stone magazine released its “500 Greatest Albums of All Time,” placing the Beatles’ “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” in the top slot.

introsecond.value: When the publication updated the list in 2012 to include the first decade of the new millennium, not only did the Beatles’ classic remain at #1 but the entire top 10 was unchanged.
This certitude wasn’t to last, though.

introthird.value: Rolling Stone revised the list in 2020 again, and the two decade consensus was no more.
Beyond “Let’s Get It On” jumping from #6 to #1 and “Pet Sounds” remaining locked in at #2, the entire top 10 was changed, some albums jumping scores of spots.

introfourth.value: Once again, here’s the 2003 ranking from twenty years ago. We’ve highlighted those albums that made the top 10 in 2020.

introfifth.value: But each year’s ranking isn’t just the same albums shuffled throughout the 500 slots.
Here is the complete ranking from 2020, and nearly a third of the albums were new, never appearing in previous rankings. Let's examine a few of these albums.

introsixtwo.value: The “new” greatest albums of all time
Many of these albums were released over the past decade, such as Kanye West’s “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy” (#17).
And Kendrick Lamar’s “To Pimp a Butterfly” (#19).

introsixthree.value: But other additions had been out for a long time, like Kate Bush’s “Hounds of Love,” originally released in 1985.
Some new additions came from even further in the past. Billie Holiday’s “Lady in Satin” made the list in 2020 despite being unranked in 2003, 45 years after its release.

popone.value: Next up: music greatness is shaped by what’s widely listened to.

Most of the albums ranked were hits when they were initially released. This might not come as a shock, but it cuts against our intuition that pop music is for the masses and truly great music is only championed by critics over time. The data shows the opposite.

poptwo.value: Here we depict the 2020 ranking, but the importance of popularity was clear across all three of Rolling Stone’s lists.
When we just look at albums ranked in the top 100, 30% charted at #1 on Billboard. Furthermore, 96% of albums were Billboard hits, at some point upon release.

popthree.value: If we look at lower ranked albums, meaning those among the bottom 400, they are 3x more likely to have never charted on Billboard. In other words, if you want your album to be considered great, it helps if it is also popular when it’s released.

spotifyone.value: In short, beyond accounting for new releases, there must be other factors influencing Rolling Stone’s choices.
This project uses Rolling Stone album rankings – twenty years apart in time – to determine what influences “greatness”.
First, music greatness is also shaped by how we listen.
Just a moment ago, we noted the turnover in Rolling Stone’s 2020 ranking: a third of albums from 2003 did not make the 2020 list.

spotifytwo.value: Here are the 174 albums from the 2003 ranking that failed to rank twenty years later.

spotifythree.value: We noticed a few qualities uniting these albums that fell out of favor with judges.

spotifyfour.value: 18% are compilations or greatest hits albums. These types of albums were popular in the days of physical releases, like CDs, cassettes, and vinyl. Today, official greatest hits collections have largely been replaced by ever-evolving playlists. In short, these types of albums have lost some of their prestige.

spotifyfive.value: 6% of the albums are also not currently available on Spotify.
For example, Captain Beefheart’s “Trout Mask Replica” was #58 in 2003. 17 years later, it failed to rank.
It’s hard for an album to remain relevant if most people don’t have a means to listen to it.

spotifysix.value: Here we add in albums unavailable on Spotify that still made Rolling Stone’s 2020 list. About half of these albums (in red) saw their ranking decline.

spotifyseven.value: Funkadelic’s genre-bending 1978 album “One Nation Under a Groove”, for example, fell from #176 to #360. The album was removed from Spotify during a dispute between Funkadelic frontman George Clinton and his former label, Warner Records.

voterone.value: Musical greatness is also shaped by who is voting.
To construct these lists, Rolling Stone polled artists, songwriters, producers, A&Rs, executives, journalists, and their staff writers. Here is who voted in 2003:

votertwo.value: Scanning these faces, something probably jumps out at you …

voterthree.value: The large, large majority of the 2003 voters were men. And while it’s difficult to pinpoint the exact racial identity of each voter, we’re confident that white men were overrepresented.

voterfour.value: For the 2020 ranking, Rolling Stone – perhaps in an effort to poll beyond the music tastes of white men – expanded the voting group from 269 to 336 and doubled the representation of women voters. Here are the judges in 2020:

voterfourtwo.value: With two cohorts of voters, from 2003 and 2020, we can reflect on how different voter demographics influence which albums are considered great.

voterfive.value: In 2003, 90% of voters were men. Not surprisingly, voters selected predominantly male performers—nearly 82% of the 500 albums selected were by men.

Rolling Stone published a few ballots of voters in 2003. Metallica’s James Hetfield only had men in his top 10 included. Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong was the same. The most gender diverse ballot, among those published, was Britney Spears’s, with Janet Jackson, Madonna, Whitney Houston, and TLC among her top 10 albums.

votersix.value: In 2020, with more women voters, we see a curious correlation with greater gender diversity in the albums selected: albums by women or mixed-gender groups jumped from 16% to 28%.
Next, let’s consider how voters’ ages shape album selection.

voterseven.value: Here are the judges, by age group, at the time of voting.
Voters in 2003 and 2020 were spread out among similar age ranges. How might this have affected the albums they selected?

votereight.value: We had a hunch that albums released during voters’ teenage years would have an outsized impact on their choices, the most formative years for music taste.
Here are judges arranged by the approximate decade of their teenage years.
In 2020, over half of the judges were teenagers in the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s. This is a stark change from the 2003 ranking, when judges were predominantly of the Baby Boomer or Gen X generation.

voternine.value: Let’s compare judges’ ages with the release years of the 500 greatest albums of all time.
In 2003, for example, only 11 voters (4%) were teens in the 1990s. In the 2003 album ranking, 74 of the 500 greatest albums of all-time (15%) were from the 1990s.

voterten.value: In 2020, the number of voters who grew up in the 1990s jumped from 11 (4%) to 90 (25%). Albums ranked in 2020 and released in the 1990s similarly increased from 15 to 21%.

votereleven.value: Of course, assessing the past is a messy, imperfect business. When Rolling Stone ranks the greatest albums of all time in 2030, a new cohort of Gen Zers will no doubt elevate albums from the 2000s and 2010s.
Yet, there is still some level of consistency over the decades, especially as we get further from the past.
Here are the 2020 albums by release decade. We’ve highlighted the albums that were also on the 2003 list, 17 years earlier.

votertwelve.value: Of the 104 albums from the 1990s on the 2020 list, 55 (53%) were on the list in 2003.

voterthirteen.value: Of the 73 albums from the 1980s on the 2020 list, 56 (76%) were on the list in 2003.

voterfourteen.value: Of the 155 albums from the 1970s on the 2020 list, 128 (83%) were on the list in 2003.

voterfifteen.value: Of the 71 albums from the 1960s on 2020 list, 65 (92%) were on the list in 2003.

votersixteen.value: Of the 10 albums from the 1950s on the 2020 list, 8 (80%) were on the in 2003.

conclusion.value: In short, after a certain point, when people are talking about great albums of the 1950s, they are likely talking about Miles Davis’s “Kind of Blue,” Elvis Presley’s self-titled album, and Frank Sinatra’s “In the Wee Small Hours,” among a few others.

Is it possible in 100 years that some obscure album from the 1950s will suddenly be hailed as the decade’s masterpiece? Yes. But it’s not likely. Some level of consensus does seem to appear over time, despite all of the unexpected non-musical factors that influence list construction.
